p: Nitrous oxide (N 2O) and nitric oxide (NO) are GHG. During the last century, their global emissions have rised, due mainly to human intervention ( IPCC, 2014). The soil emits both N 2O and NO. N 2O is a strong GHG, whereas NO contributes indirectly to O 3 synthesis. As GHG, N 2O is potentially 300 times stronger than CO 2. Once in the stratosphere, the former catalyzes the elimination of O 3 ( IPCC, 2014). In the atmosphere, N 2O concentrations are climbing up due mainly to microbial activity in nitrogen (N)-rich soils related with agricultural and fertilization practices ( Hall et al., 2008).
